text: Is there oversight at board, executive, and management levels on how the company’s policies and practices affect freedom of expression and privacy?
name: C2. Governance and management oversight

text: Does the company have mechanisms in place to implement its commitment to freedom of expression and privacy?
name: C3. Internal implementation

text: Does the company conduct regular, comprehensive, and credible due diligence, such as human rights impact assessments, to identify how all aspects of their business impact freedom of expression and privacy?
name: C4. Impact assessment

text: Does the company engage with a range of stakeholders on freedom of expression and privacy issues?
name: C5. Stakeholder engagement

text: Does the company have grievance and remedy mechanisms?
name: C6. Remedy

text: Are the company’s Terms of Service freely available and easy to understand?
name: F1. Availability of Terms of Service

text: Does the company commit to provide meaningful notice and documentation to users when it changes its Terms of Service?
name: F2. Terms of Service, notice and record of changes

text: Does the company disclose whether it prohibits certain types of content or activities?
name: F3. Reasons for content restriction

text: Does the company explain the circumstances under which it may restrict or deny users from accessing the service?
name: F4. Reasons for account or service restriction

text: If the company restricts content or access, does it disclose how it notifies users?
name: F5. Notify users of restriction

text: Does the company publish information about its process for evaluating and responding to requests from governments and other third parties to restrict content or service?
name: F6. Process for responding to third-party requests

text: Does the company regularly publish data about government requests (including judicial orders) to remove, filter, or restrict content or access to service, plus data about the extent to which the company complies with such requests?
name: F7. Data about government requests

text: Does the company regularly publish data about requests from non-governmental (and non-judicial) parties to remove, filter, or restrict access to content, plus data about the extent to which the company complies with such requests?
name: F8. Data about private requests

text: Does the company regularly publish information about the volume and nature of actions taken to enforce the company’s own terms of service?
name: F9. Data about Terms of Service enforcement

text: Does the company disclose whether it prioritizes or degrades transmission or delivery of different types of content (e.g, traffic shaping or throttling) and if so, for what purpose?
name: F10. Network management

text: Does the company require users to verify their identity with government-issued identification, or with other forms of identification connected to their offline identity?
name: F11. Identity policy

text: Are the company’s privacy policies freely available and easy to understand?
name: P1. Availability of Privacy Policies

text: Does the company commit to provide meaningful notice and documentation to users when it changes its privacy policies?
name: P2. Privacy Policies, notice and record of changes

text: Does the company disclose what user information it collects, how it collects this information, and why?
name: P3. Collection of user information

text: Does the company disclose if and how it shares user information with third parties?
name: P4. Sharing of user information

text: Does the company provide users with options to control the company’s collection and sharing of their information?
name: P5. User control over information collection and sharing

text: Are users able to view, download or otherwise obtain, in structured data formats, information about them that the company holds?
name: P6. Users’ access to their own information

text: Does the company disclose how long it retains user information?
name: P7. Retention of user information

text: Does the company publish clear information about whether it collects user information from third parties?
name: P8. Collection of user information from third parties

text: Does the company publish information about its process for evaluating and responding to requests from government and other third parties for stored user data and/or real-time communications, including the legal basis for complying with such requests?
name: P9. Process for responding to third-party requests for user information

text: Does the company commit to notify users to the extent legally possible when their data has been requested by governments and other third parties?
name: P10. User notification about third-party requests for user information

text: Does the company regularly publish data about government and other third-party requests for user information, plus data about the extent to which the company complies with such requests?
name: P11. Data about third-party requests for user information

text: Does the company deploy industry standards of encryption and security for its products and services?
name: P12. Security standards

text: Can users encrypt their own content and thereby control who has access to it?
name: P13. Encryption of users’ private content

text: Does the company publish information to help users defend against cyber threats?
name: P14. Inform and educate users about potential threats
